questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : FINANCIAL FORENSICS (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? question_texts: All of the following are non current assets except:

questions.question_text_1: Mr. Steven started a furniture business with ₹ 55,00,000 as capital. 40% of the amount was brought in cash and the remaining was kept in a bank account in the name of the business. What would be the total of assets in the Balance sheet?
question_texts: Mr. Steven started a furniture business with ₹ 55,00,000 as capital. 40% of the amount was brought in cash and the remaining was kept in a bank account in the name of the business. What would be the total of assets in the Balance sheet?

questions.question_text_1: All of the following are long-term liabilities except:
question_texts: All of the following are long-term liabilities except:

questions.question_text_1: XYZ Inc. hired a factory shed for monthly rent of ₹ 65,000. In the month of July 2022 the business paid only 30% of the rent at the end of the month and the rest was outstanding. The rental expenses in the income statement for the month of July will be
question_texts: XYZ Inc. hired a factory shed for monthly rent of ₹ 65,000. In the month of July 2022 the business paid only 30% of the rent at the end of the month and the rest was outstanding. The rental expenses in the income statement for the month of July will be

options.option_text: Not an expense till the full amount is paid

questions.question_text_1: A business invested ₹ 15,00,000 in a bank in the form of fixed deposit. The transaction will result in
question_texts: A business invested ₹ 15,00,000 in a bank in the form of fixed deposit. The transaction will result in

options.option_text: Increase in assets and decrease in liability
Increase in liability and decrease in assets

questions.question_text_1: At the beginning of the month the company hired workers and employees for a total monthly remuneration of ₹ 78,000 payable at the end of each month. How would this transaction reflect in the income statement and balance sheet at the beginning of the month?
question_texts: At the beginning of the month the company hired workers and employees for a total monthly remuneration of ₹ 78,000 payable at the end of each month. How would this transaction reflect in the income statement and balance sheet at the beginning of the month?

options.option_text: Expense will increase by ₹ 78,000 and liabilities will also increase by equalamount
Expense will increase by ₹ 78,000 and cash will decrease by the equal amount
There will be no effect on both the statement

questions.question_text_1: An amount of ₹ 2,50,000 was spent towards advertisement and sales promotion activities. The payment was made through cheque. The amount was decided to be amortized over a period of 5 years. What would be the amortization expense for the first year and the unamortized amount in the balance sheet at the end of the first year
question_texts: An amount of ₹ 2,50,000 was spent towards advertisement and sales promotion activities. The payment was made through cheque. The amount was decided to be amortized over a period of 5 years. What would be the amortization expense for the first year and the unamortized amount in the balance sheet at the end of the first year

question_texts: If Roobes & Co. had bought raw materials worth Rs. 5,00,000, for a trade discount of 10% and cash discount of 20% for making immediate payment, the gross amount that would show under the head purchases will be

question_texts: Purchase of goods on cash basis reduces cash and increases

questions.question_text_1: Depreciation is
question_texts: Depreciation is

options.option_text: Reduction in value of the asset due to market movement
Is only a hypothetical number used to reduce profits
The amount spent on buying the asset
Reduction in value of the asset due to/and usage and passage of time

questions.question_text_1: Dividend to the shareholders are paid out of
question_texts: Dividend to the shareholders are paid out of

options.option_text: Profit before interest depreciation and tax
